title: Attributes Accepted for PHP 8
description: <> class Release { public function __construct(protected SemVer $version) {} }

title: PHP Will Have str_contains()
description:
Estimates are hard...
A function that checks if a string is contained in another string? I'd say 3 story points.

25 years later...

title: Language evolution proposal from Nikita
description: Nikita has started a discussion about how to keep PHP moving forward without breaking legacy code.

title: Implementation notes on Generics in PHP
description: Will we ever see generics in PHP? Nikita published a study of the possibility and revealed possible difficulties.

title: PHP 7.4
description: The most recent huge update for the language included typed properties, arrow functions, numeric literal separator, allowed exceptions from __toString(), of course opcache preloading, and even more.

title: PSR-12 Extended Coding Style Guide accepted
P++ discussion
description: The controversy and accusations in PHP Internals over the removal of short tags and other discussions eventually resulted in a proposal from Zeev Suraski – create a new PHP dialect called P++, like C++ for C. PHP and P++ were supposed to be developed side by side within a single runtime. But after a straw poll it didn't move further.

title: Zend Framework became Laminas
description: The framewroks transitioned to Linux Foundation and has been renamed to Laminas, to detach it from commercial brand Zend.

title: Narrow Margins for RFCs were abolished
Perforce acquired Rogue Wave Software which owned Zend
The Xdebug Experience
description: Derick Rethans left MongoDB, and started a new jorney working on Xdebug almost exclusively.

title: Nikita Popov Joins Phpstorm Team
description: A well-known long-time PHP ecosystem contributor, joined JetBrains to work with the PhpStorm team on improving the PHP language and ecosystem.

title: PHP 7.3
description: The release brought updates for Heredoc and Nowdoc strings, trailing comma in arguments list, new hrtime() function, improved garbage collection, and some other features.

title: Zeev Suraski Leaves Zend
description: The end of an era – the second of two founders left the company. Matthew Weier O'Phinney and Enrico Zimuel left the company too.

title: PHP FFI announced
description: TODO text

title: Psalm 1.0
description: TODO text

title: PSR-15 HTTP Server Request Handlers Accepted
description: The standard layed down how to write request handlers middlewares in PHP.

title: PHP-PM 1.0
description: TODO text

title: Keep it simple stupid: RemoteOK.io is a single "index.php" file generating $2,342.04 in a day. No frameworks. No libraries.
PHP 7.2
description: This released made PHP the first programming language with modern cryptography in its standard library thanks to the bundled libsodium. It also brought object typehint, parameter type widening, and a few other things.

title: HHVM's last release that commits to PHP support
InfectionPHP 0.1
description: TODO text

title: Amphp 2.0
description: TODO text

title: End of HHVM support in popular projects
description: Symfony, Laravel, Doctrine, MongoDB driver, Twig, Silex, Swiftmailer, and many other major tools declared stop of the HHVM support.

title: PSR-11 Container Interface Accepted
description: With this standard we can reuse

title: PHP 7.1
description: The update brought another speed-up, as well as nullable types, class constant visiblity modifiers, void return type, and other things.

title: PHP-FIG 3.0 – the new bylaws of the group
Laravel, Propel, Doctrine, The PHP League, and Guzzle resigned from PHP-FIG
PhpStorm 2016.1
description: The first PhpStorm release with a new YYYY.R versioning model.

title: PHP 7.0
description: A major language renewal gave him a new life. It came with a new Zend Engine 3 (PHPNG), numerous improvements and new features and up to twice as fast as previous PHP 5.6.

title: Rogue Wave acquired Zend
description: Zend company, who stand behind the language since PHP 3, is not a flagship anymore.

title: A Field Guide to Elephpants started
PHP turned 20
description: Many developers back then published their PHP-story.

title: PSR-7 Accepted
description: The standard finally settled how to deal with HTTP requests and responses in an OOP way.

title: Lumen released for the first time
PSR-0 deprecated in favor of PSR-4
PHP-Parser 1.0
description: A PHP parser written in PHP allowed to create many tools on top of it.

title: PHP 5.6
description: This last major PHP 5 release brought constant scalar expressions, splat ... operator for variadic functions and argument unpacking, function and constant importing with the use keyword, phpdbg as an integrated debugger, operator overloading (yeah PHP has it) for GMP objects.

title: PHP Language Specification
description: Despite its popularity and considerable age, PHP had never had a formal specification until 2014. It was inittially developed in Facebook and later dedicated all copyright to the public domain worldwide.

title: PHPNG First Announced
description: It all started with Dmitry Stogov's message in php.internals, and as a result, a new generation PHP interpreter was introduced, which became the basis of PHP 7.

title: Facebook Introduced Hack
description: Hack programming language was born as PHP dialect and extended it with a number of new features. Some of the successful solutions have since been transferred to PHP, and continue to inspire developers.

title: PSR-8 Mutually Assured Hug published
description: https://twitter.com/Mark_Baker/status/1259913506993967104

title: The League of Extraordinary Packages has started
ElisLab looking for new owner for CodeIgniter
PHP 5.5
description: This released introduced generators and coroutines, finally keyword, scalar class name resolution via ::class, and many more. On of the greatests things it brought was the bundled Zend OPcache extension which made opcade caching available and opened a door to more performance optimizations.

title: Laravel 4
description: Illuminate, also known as Laravel 4 was re-written from the ground up as a collection of components that integrate with each other to make up a framework. And that's when the Facades came in.

title: Stack — the first middlewares in PHP
React v0.3
description: This was the first public release of the ReactPHP, which proved the async model can be in PHP applications. Back then React.js was not yet a thing, so it was called just React.

title: PHP version 5.3 was the most used version, just ahead of 5.2
PHP The Right Way
description: The "Right Way" became a starting of PHP wisdom and best practices for developers all around the world.

title: PSR-1, PSR-2 Accepted
description: The end of tabs vs spaces war!

title: PHP: a fractal of bad design
description: That post overviewed many problems PHP had back then. Many of them had been fixed later, but PHP hateers still refer to the article as a source of truth.

title: PHP 5.4
description: New major version of PHP introduced significant improvуment of performance, memory footprint and fixing of over 100 bugs. New features included traits, shortened array syntax, built-in webserver for testing purposes and more.

title: Laravel 3
description: Laravel 3 was released along with a shiny new website and great new features of the framework: unit test integration, the Artisan command line interface, database migrations, events, more session drivers and database drivers, integration for “bundles” and more.

title: Laravel 2
description: Major new features included the support for controllers, which made Laravel 2 a fully MVC-compliant framework, built-in support for the inversion of control (IoC) principle, and a templating system called Blade.

title: Composer
description:
By the 2011 all major languages already had their package managers: npm, Bundler, pip, NuGet. Coming last, PHP received a state-of-the-art tool thanks to Jordi Boggiano, Nils Adermann, and contributors.
OHAI PHP DEVS, Y U NO PACKAGE?

title: Laravel 1
description: Taylor Otwell created Laravel as an attempt to provide a more advanced alternative to the CodeIgniter framework. It revolutionized the whole PHP landscape since then.

title: Guzzle 1.0
description: TODO text

title: FuelPHP
description: TODO text

title: FastCGI Process Manager (FPM)
description: FPM (FastCGI Process Manager) is an alternative PHP FastCGI implementation with some additional features (mostly) useful for heavy-loaded sites and was merged in PHP 5.3 codebase in 2010.

title: Slim 1
description: Probably the first PHP micro framework as we know them today.

title: PSR-0 Accepted
description: After PHP has received namespaces, it could finally have a proper autoloading too. Before this first PSR standard accepted, PHP files looked like insane mix of includes and requires.

title: Unofficial PHP Anthem
description: ItsLeeOwen · PHP Anthem

title: PhpStorm 1.0 Released
description: Previously known under a working name Web IDE, PhpStorm has been released with support for Xdebug, PHPUnit, and Zend Framework.

title: PHP 6 officially abandoned
description: TODO text https://lwn.net/Articles/379909/

title: PHP-FIG Gathered
description: People representing various PHP projects met at php|tek conference in 2009, and that's when the idea of PHP-FIG (Framework Interoperability Group) group was born. The FIG's recommendations called PSRs drastycally changed the landscape of the PHP ecosystem.

title: PHP 5.3
description: The release braught so anticipated support for namespaces, late static binding, and anonymous functions that finally made PHP a mature language.

title: Yii version 1
description: The RAD framework daeveloped by the PRADO author. Many ideas and some code were taken from PRADO, including: ActiveRecord, i18n, l10n, etc. Yii also drew more inspirations from RoR (convention over configuration, some AR features), Symfony1 (filters, plugins) and Joomla (modules, message translation).

title: PHP 6 Book
description: PHP 6 was never released but the book "Fast and Easy Web Development." is still available on the Internet.

title: Facebook PHP Source Code Leaked
description: In August 2007 a hacker found a way to expose the PHP source code on facebook.com. He retrieved two files index.php and search.php.

title: Xdebug 2.0
description: Improved stack traces, execution traces to files, code coverage analysis and much improved remote debugging support — the features that one might think were there since forever, in fact were added in Xdebug 2.

title: ElePHPant – the Furry PHP Mascot
description: Brought to the world thanks to Damien Seguy based on Vincent Pontier's design.

title: PHP developers meeting in Paris
description: PHP 6 idea first discussed.

title: PHP 5.2
description: With a new memory manager for the Zend Engine and new features such as input filtering, JSON and ZIP extensions, tracking file upload progress, date and time objects, PHP 5.2 was a big success and remained the most popular version until 2013.

title: Zend Framework initial release
description: Zend Framework is probably one of the first that was developed as a set of reusable components. TODO one more sentence.

title: CodeIgniter 1
description: CodeIgniter was one of the first rapid development frameworks. It's not only alive and popular in present, but it also inspered developers to develop many subsequent frameworks like Laravel, FuelPHP, Kohana, and Yii.

title: PHP 5.1
description: PHP 5.1's new features included a complete rewrite of date handling code, with improved timezone support, PDO enabled by default, significant performance improvements compared to PHP 5.0.

title: Symfony project kicked off
description: Fabien Potencier made the first import of the Symfony 1 code to the Subversion repository (see changeset).

title: PHP 6 With Unicode Support Initiated
description: https://news-web.php.net/php.internals/17668

title: PRADO version 1
description: The first framework using PHP 5. Prado was inspired by Apache Tapestry, Borland Delphi and Microsoft ASP.NET.

title: PHP 5.0
description: Some of the key features of PHP 5 included: - The Zend Engine II with a new object model; - New extensions: SimpleXML, SOAP, MySQLi, SQLite; - Greatly improved streams, including the ability to access  low-level socket operations.

title: Facebook.com launched as a simple, server-rendered PHP website
Dmitry Stogov Joined Zend
description: Dmitry joined Zend and helped develop most of the core PHP subsystems during PHP 5's life. Later, Dmitry lead the PHPNG project, which brought the speed of PHP 7 to a new level. Currently, Dmitry works at Zend by Perforce as a Principal Engineer and leads the development of the JIT compiler for PHP.

title: First Release of WordPress
description:
The most popular CMS in the world first appeared in 2003 a fork of b2. It used the same file structure as its predecessor, and continued the numbering from its last release, 0.6.
Main releases of WordPress are codenamed after well-known jazz musicians, starting from version 1.0.
As of today, WordPress is used by more than one third of all the websites.

title: PHP Look Back by Derick Rethans
description:
On 11-Feb Erik was wondering if people who "keep telling me PHP is a dead end, it's in fact a dying language." are just making it up or not.

Yeah, well, nothing has changed. PHP's unofficial slogan: Dying since 1995.

title: Turck MMCache for PHP Released
description: The ancestor of the modern OPCache.

title: Phrame — the First MVC Framework in PHP
APC First Released
description: The PHP accelarator of the pre-OPcache era.

title: Initial commit of PHPUnit
description: Sebastian Bergmann started the work on the most used PHP testing framework. It was inspired by SUnit and JUnit.

title: Smarty Released
description:
The most known templating engine for PHP.
Rasmus realised that he failed when people started writing tempalte enginges for his template engine in his template engine.

title: PHP Coding Standard
description: Probably the first one.

title: leak()
description: Did you know PHP had leak() function that was used to actually leak a specified amount of memory. Is this where it all the rumors come from? 🤔

title: First PHP Conferences
description: The first PHP conference announced was the one in Japan. It was followed by PHP conference in Germany in October, 2000 that evolved into International PHP Conference which is still held.

title: PHP Quality Assurance Initiative
description: A new initiative called PHP Quality assurance was created in summer of 2000 in response to criticism that PHP releases were not being tested well enough for production environments.

title: PHP 4.0
description: PHP 4 came with a brand new core 'Zend Engine' developed by Andi and Zeev. The design goals were to improve performance of complex applications, and improve the modularity of PHP's code base. In addition to the highly improved performance of this version, PHP 4 included other key features such as support for more web servers, HTTP sessions, output buffering, and several new language constructs.

title: Initial Release of Drupal
description: Originally written as a message board, Drupal became an open source project in 2001 and grew into the one of the most popular CMS systems.

title: PEAR Appeared
description: PEAR, the PHP Extension and Application Repository (originally, PHP Extension and Add-on Repository) is PHP's version of foundation classes, and was one of the key ways to distribute PHP extensions among developers. PEAR was born in discussions held in the PHP Developers' Meeting (PDM) held in January 2000 in Tel Aviv.

title: PHP Developers' Meeting
description:
The first face to face meeting that included (almost) everyone who was working on PHP.
How many people can you name?

title: Zend Company Was Founded
description: The name Zend is a combination of Suraski's and Gutmans' forenames, Zeev and Andi. Zend company stands behind PHP innovations and development since the first days. Bringing core improvements as well as userland packages and frameworks and development environment tooling.

title: ElePHPant Logo
description: Vincent Pontier created an elePHPant logo for the PHP project which was ever since the adorable mascot of the PHP language.

title: phpMyAdmin Project Was “Born”
description: Tobias Ratschiller released version 0.9.0 of the web administration tool for MySQL that for long time remained one of the primary tools for accessing MySQL and MySQL-like databases.

title: PHP 3.0
description:
PHP 3.0 was the first version that closely resembles PHP as it exists today. Zeev Suraski and Andi Gutmans rewrote the parser and formed the base of this version. With many new developers from around the world on board, PHP 3 was announced by the new PHP Development Team.
The language's changed to the recursive acronym PHP: Hypertext Preprocessor. At its peak, PHP 3 was installed on approximately 10% of the web servers on the Internet.

title: PHP Logo
description: Colin Viebrock

title: Netcraft Survey
description: In 1997 and 1998, PHP/FI had a cult of several thousand users around the world. A Netcraft survey as of May 1998, indicated that nearly 60,000 domains domains reported having headers containing "PHP," indicating that the host server did indeed have it installed. This number equated to approximately 1% of all domains on the Internet at the time. Despite these impressive figures, the maturation of PHP/FI was doomed to limitations; while there were several minor contributors, it was still primarily developed by an individual.

title: First PHP Book: "Tvorba interaktivních internetových aplikací"
description: The first book dedicated to PHP was 'PHP - tvorba interaktivních internetových aplikací' (PHP - Creating Interactive Internet Applications) - a Czech book published in April 1999, authored by Jirka Kosek. Next month followed a German book authored by Egon Schmid, Christian Cartus and Richard Blume. The first book in English about PHP was published shortly afterwards, and was 'Core PHP Programming' by Leon Atkinson. These books covered PHP 3.0.

title: Andi Gutmans & Zeev Suraski Joined the Project
description: Finding PHP/FI 2.0 still inefficient and lacking features they needed to power an eCommerce application they were developing for a university project, Andi Gutmans and Zeev Suraski of Tel Aviv, Israel, began yet another complete rewrite of the underlying parser in 1997. Approaching Rasmus online, they discussed various aspects of the current implementation and their redevelopment of PHP.

title: PHP 2.0
description: PHP/FI was given a version 2.0 status. An interesting fact about this, however, is that there was only one single full version of PHP 2.0. When it finally graduated from beta status in November, 1997, the underlying parsing engine was already being entirely rewritten.

title: PHP/FI
description: The code got another complete makeover, and in April of 1996, combining the names of past releases, Rasmus introduced PHP/FI. This second-generation implementation began to truly evolve PHP from a suite of tools into a programming language in its own right. It included built-in support for DBM, mSQL, and Postgres95 databases, cookies, user-defined function support, and much more.

title: Personal Home Page Construction Kit
description:
In October 1995, Rasmus released a complete rewrite of the code. Bringing back the PHP name, it was now (briefly) named "Personal Home Page Construction Kit" and was the first release to boast what was, at the time, considered an advanced scripting interface.
The language was deliberately designed to resemble C in structure, making it an easy adoption for developers familiar with C, Perl, and similar languages.

title: FI
description: In September 1995, Rasmus expanded upon PHP and – for a short time – actually dropped the PHP name. Now referring to the tools as FI (short for "Forms Interpreter"), the new implementation included some of the basic functionality of PHP as we know it today.

title: PHP Tools – the Birth of PHP
description: In June 1995 Rasmus announced and released PHP Tools to the public.

title: Why oldest core functions have inconsistent names?
description: Back when PHP had less than 100 functions and the function hashing mechanism was strlen(). In order to get a nice hash distribution of function names across the various function name lengths names were picked specifically to make them fit into a specific length bucket.

title: Rasmus Lerdorf Started Working on PHP
description: The very first incarnation of PHP was a simple set of Common Gateway Interface (CGI) binaries written in the C programming language (not Perl). Originally used for tracking visits to Rasmus Lerdorf's online resume, he named the suite of scripts "Personal Home Page Tools," more frequently referenced as "PHP Tools."
